entry.title: HTML Arrow – Symbol Unicode for Single and Double Arrows, Left and Right Arrows
entry.summary: What are Unicodes? Unicodes are universal characters that represent different things. These could be symbols, characters, scripts, and many more forms of character combinations. Unicodes are adopted by many platforms (mobile and web) to make characters available everywhere. Why are Unicodes useful? Unicodes are useful because they provide a standard

entry.title: Learn Visual Basic (.NET) – Full Course
entry.summary: Did you know that Visual Basic is currently a more popular programming language than JavaScript? That is according to the TIOBE index [https://www.tiobe.com/tiobe-index/], which is one of the most respected indicators of the popularity of programming languages. Visual Basic is an object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft. It makes it

entry.title: How To Easily Build And Support Tables In Figma
entry.summary: In this article, Andrii shares his approach to managing tables in Figma in an easier, more streamlined way when there is a need to support different screen resolutions, change the order of columns, and use real-life content.

entry.title: How to Query Data in Google Spreadsheets
entry.summary: I built a spreadsheet and wanted to display some of the data in a small table which would update based on the day of the week. After some digging, querying seemed the best option to pull this off. In this article, you'll learn several things about Google Sheets tables, functions,

entry.title: How to Solve the Parking Lot Challenge in JavaScript
entry.summary: Have you heard about the Parking Lot challenge? If not, let me explain briefly. The Parking Lot is challenge where you are asked to write a class that manages an imaginary parking lot. In this tutorial we will do that in JavaScript. And to make it a bit more

entry.summary: When working with arrays, there will be times when you need to loop or iterate through the array's values in order to either output or manipulate them. entry.title: Web Design Done Well: Delightful Data Visualization Examples
entry.summary: All the data in the world won’t do anyone any good if we can’t make sense of it. Or better yet, make it sing. Here are some stunning examples of data visualization in the wild, and some pointers on how to start making your own.

entry.title: How to Help Translate freeCodeCamp into Your Native Language

So instead of relying on machine translation, we are doing this entire process by hand. Dozens of native speakers are collaborating to make these free learning resources accessible to more people

entry.title: CRUD Operations – What is CRUD?
entry.summary: Despite being commonly pronounced /krʌd/, CRUD is not a word. It’s an abbreviation that stands for Create, Read, Update, and Delete or Destroy. In this article, I will show you what CRUD means, and what the individual terms mean and do. I will also show you how create, read, update,

entry.title: Text Classification with TensorFlow
entry.summary: Text classification algorithms are used in a lot of different software systems to help process text data. For example, when you get an email, the email software uses a text classification algorithm to decide whether to put it in your inbox or in your spam folder. It's also how discussion

entry.title: The Guide To Windows High Contrast Mode
entry.summary: In this article, we’ll see how to make our sites friendly for Windows High Contrast Mode by using a good set of practices, including the media query `forced-colors` and its toolset.

entry.title: Adding Search To Your Site In 15 Minutes
entry.summary: Do you need search for your site, but haven’t found the time to add it? Within 15 minutes, Leonardo Losoviz explains how you can add a super powerful search that also looks super good. In this article, you’ll learn how to go from 0 to 100 with search.

entry.title: How To Apply UX Principles To Embedded Systems: Learnings From The Field
entry.summary: In this article, Eva gives an overview of what embedded systems are and how they impact our lives. She presents three main learnings gained across her quest for creating better-embedded systems to enable the world as we know it.

entry.title: DevFest For Ukraine, A Charity Conference On The Future Of Tech 🇺🇦
entry.summary: [DevFest for Ukraine](https://devfest.gdg.org.ua/) is a charitable online conference that will bring together 20 industry-leading tech speakers in support of Ukraine. June 14–15.

entry.title: Measuring The Performance Of Typefaces For Users (Part 2)
entry.summary: In this article, Thomas Bohm explains ways to test typefaces and other typographic issues. Though this article is slightly high-end and academic, fear not. The content will be interesting, especially for committed typeface designers and typographers. If you like complex issues and problems, this is for you.

entry.title: The Future Of Frontend Build Tools
entry.summary: This article explores the evolution and the future of frontend tooling, presenting a new set of tools featuring a change in paradigm, platform, or both.

entry.title: Simplify Your Color Palette With CSS Color-Mix()
entry.summary: CSS color-mix is an experimental function that blends two colors and can be used to simplify color palettes. You can define a color palette and theme without too much effort using CSS color-mix().

entry.title: Digital Museums For Digital History
entry.summary: Computer technologies have simplified the process of recording historical events, technological breakthroughs, contemporary art, and everyday life. However, the notion of digital archiving can be deceptive. Often our technical footprints are carved in sand rather than stone.

entry.title: The Case For Prisma In The Jamstack
entry.summary: In this article, Sam Poder explores how Prisma integrates with the Jamstack and why it’s a great solution for Serverless databases in JavaScript or TypeScript-based projects.

entry.title: Measuring The Performance Of Typefaces For Users (Part 1)
entry.summary: This is the first part of this article, written especially for typeface designers and typographers. See how typefaces work, how to test them, and other broader typographic issues.

entry.title: How To Build A Group Chat App With Vanilla JS, Twilio And Node.js
entry.summary: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create a group chat app. You will build a backend app using Node.js that will make group chats, authorize chat participants, and maintain sessions for them.

entry.title: Don’t Sink Your Website With Third Parties
entry.summary: In this article, Ken Harker explains what third-party resource requests really are and which common optimization strategies can help reduce the impact on the user experience. By carefully considering how third-party requests will fit into your website during the design stage, you’ll be able to avoid the most significant negative impacts.

entry.title: Expand Your Horizons (June 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)
entry.summary: What could be a better way to welcome June than with some colorful inspiration? Well, we might have something for you: wallpapers created with love by artists and designers from across the globe.

entry.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 47 With Sara Soueidan: Why Does Accessibility Matter?
entry.summary: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast, we ask why accessibility really matters and why it is so important to get it right. Smashing’s Vitaly Friedman talks in-depth to Sara Soueidan to find out.

entry.title: What’s That (Dev) Tool?
entry.summary: How many browser DevTools panels do you commonly use in your day-to-day web development? One? Three? Probably not that many more. In this article, Patrick Brosset shines the spotlight on a number of tools that people don’t use or even know about. Let’s dive in!

entry.title: Open-Source 3dicons Library: Case Study And Free Downloads
entry.summary: In this article, Vijay describes his learning experiences during the design stages of creating his 3dicons image library (a free library for product screens, social media posts and marketing campaigns), which you can download and use for free.

entry.title: Manage Accessible Design System Themes With CSS Color-Contrast()
entry.summary: From working with design handoffs to supporting custom themes in a design system, the CSS `color-contrast()` function can become a cornerstone for developers by enforcing accessible UIs.

entry.title: Understanding Weak Reference In JavaScript
entry.summary: In this article, Frank Joseph explains both weak and strong references in JavaScript, as well as the concept of reachability. Let’s dig in!

entry.title: Developing An Award-Winning Onboarding Process (Case Study)
entry.summary: This article is a case study of how the platformOS team has researched, developed, and iteratively adjusted their onboarding processes over more than three years to eventually create the multiple award winning developer experience they provide today.

entry.title: Lesser-Known And Underused CSS Features In 2022
entry.summary: CSS is constantly evolving, and some cool and useful properties either go completely unnoticed or are not talked about as much as others for some reason or another. In this article, we’ll cover a fraction of those CSS properties and selectors.

entry.title: The Ultimate Free Solo Blog Setup With Ghost And Gatsby
entry.summary: In this article, we will see step-by-step how you can get the best of customization with easy admin by using Ghost as a headless CMS for a Gatsby static site — everything for free.
